description: A plank with a handle and a whittled-down point.  It's only a facsimile of a sword, but might serve for training or just knocking heads.
A plank with a handle and a whittled-down point, left large enough to require two hands.  It's only a facsimile of a sword, but might serve for training or just knocking heads.
A vicious single-edged sword made out of sheet metal layered twice over itself then welded together.  It's not as robust as a proper forged sword, but the edge is wickedly sharp.
A long-handled single-edged sword made out of sheet metal layered thrice over itself then welded together.  The extra length and weight makes it a tad awkward, but gives it a lot of slashing power.
A hand-forged approximation of a medieval weapon.  It's certainly sharp enough to get the job done, but the simplistic design is clearly inferior to the real thing.
A large, crudely-forged blade.  It's too big to be called a sword.  Too massive, too thick, too heavy, and far too rough.
A large blade with one end wrapped in duct tape to make a crude handle, making it easier to wield as a rough machete.
This intimidating blade makes an excellent tool for chopping through vegetation, or anything else you don't want in your yard.
A thin, wobbly steel blade with sawteeth on one side and a flat chisel tip for digging.  More of a jackass of all trades than a jack of them.
A curved sword associated with cavalry from the Early Modern period onward.  Lightweight, but a deadly slashing weapon.

An ancient Chinese doubled-edged straight sword, with an ornate guard and a tassel attached to the pommel.  One of the four major weapons in folklore, alongside the dao sabre, qiang spear, and gun staff.
A curved sword associated with various Middle Eastern and Central Asian countries.  Designed for slashing, and quite deadly against unarmored targets.
Also called a tuck, the estoc is a very long thrusting sword designed for piercing armor on the battlefield.

A classic medieval sword, in between the lighter arming sword and later two-handed swords in size.  It's well-balanced and surprisingly easy to use due to its two-handed grip, but requires a larger baldric or scabbard compared to smaller swords.
A classic medieval sword, just the right size to use one-handed.
A bronze sword of ancient Greek origin.

This ancient bronze weapon features a curved, sickle-like blade sharpened on the outside edge.  Associated with the New Kingdom period of Ancient Egypt, it was designed mainly to hack through the light armor common to the region.
An ancient Chinese saber consisting of a curved blade and a guard with a cupped design.  This one is made of bronze.
A simple short sword made of bronze.
A long, knife bladed bayonet that can be attached to the front of a rifle, converting it into a pike.  It is long enough to be used as a short sword when unmounted.
An ornate knife that dates back to the Heian period in Japan.  Originally a backup weapon for samurai, these blades took on a ceremonial purpose, becoming the instrument used for seppuku.
A comparatively-common Japanese short sword.  Smaller and lighter than a katana, but still effective in combat.
A glass shard with wrapping at one end so it can be safely wielded.
A huge two-handed sword from Germany.  It packs a real wallop.
A traditional Indonesian small knife.  This one is sharp and could be an effective weapon.
A ceremonial dagger carried by Sikh men.  This one is sharp and could be an effective weapon.
A two-handed sword from Japan resembling an extremely long katana.
A weapon used for fencing, the most noble of all sports.  Unfortunately, a fencing foil is rather useless as a weapon due to its flexible shaft and dull tip.

What was once a mostly-harmless fencing foil has had its electrical plunger assembly removed and has been crudely sharpened to a point.  Though it still lacks a cutting edge, it is now somewhat more lethal, yet still familiar to the practiced fencer.

The modifications made to this fencing foil may not be sporting, but they might give you an edge in this final competition.  Extra effort has been made to insulate the grip and a high voltage stun gun has been attached to the guard, wired through the electronic scoring circuit to the tip.  Thrusting the sharpened tip into a foe and activating the momentary switch will deliver a painful electric shock.

A weapon used for fencing, the most noble of all sports.  While not designed for combat the épée is the heaviest and stiffest of the fencing weapons, and therefore perhaps still useful in your situation.

What was once a mostly-harmless fencing épée has had its electrical plunger assembly removed and has been crudely sharpened to a point.  Though it still lacks a cutting edge, it is now considerably more lethal, yet still familiar to the practiced fencer.

The modifications made to this fencing épée may not be sporting, but they might give you an edge in this final competition.  Extra effort has been made to insulate the grip and a high voltage stun gun has been attached to the guard, wired through the electronic scoring circuit to the tip.  Thrusting the sharpened tip into a foe and activating the momentary switch will deliver a painful electric shock.
Unlike most cavalry sabers, the fencing saber is straight, and stouter than the foil or épée.  Designed for sport rather than real combat, it has a rounded tip and dull edges.

What was once a mostly-harmless fencing saber has had its rounded tip snapped off and has been crudely sharpened to a point.  Though it still lacks a cutting edge, it is now considerably more lethal, yet still familiar to the practiced fencer.

The modifications made to this fencing saber may not be sporting, but they might give you an edge in this final competition.  Extra effort has been made to insulate the grip and a high voltage stun gun has been attached to the guard, wired to the tip along the saber's groove.  Thrusting the sharpened tip into a foe and activating the momentary switch will deliver a painful electric shock.
A cane designed to conceal a blade.  This was a popular fashion accessory for the wealthy during the 18th and 19th centuries.
A sword with a thin blade designed to be hidden inside a hollow cane.
A straight sword that was ubiquitous during the Early Modern era, with a wide blade suitable for slashing or stabbing.  These were called "broad" to contrast with the slimmer rapiers of the day.
A thin, straight sword of the type once preferred by musketeers, masked gentlemen, and swashbucklers of all sorts.
A slightly curved sword from Japan, world-famous for its artistic design and association with the age of the samurai.
A Shaolin butterfly sword, short, with a handguard and an unusually wide blade.  These are traditionally used in pairs, but just one is more than enough.
A broad saber known for its use by sailors and pirates, as its short blade is easy to handle in close quarters.

A single-edged two-handed sword of German design, with a long, curved blade.  It became popular across Europe due to its low cost while maintaining strong cutting power in comparison to the more sophisticated longsword.
A distinct Dacian sword that curves forward, allowing you to bypass shields or hook and pull enemies, while delivering decent chopping damage.
A chainsaw that has been lightened, tuned, and extensively modified to be easier to handle as a weapon.  Unfortunately, these modifications have rendered it much less effective as a woodcutting tool.

success_message.str: With a snarl, the <npc_name> screams to life!

failure_message.str: You yank the cord, but nothing happens.

description: This combat chainsaw is on, and is continuously draining gasoline.  Use it to turn it off.

An electric chainsaw that has been lightened, tuned, and extensively modified to be easier to handle as a weapon.  Unfortunately, these modifications have rendered it much less effective as a woodcutting tool.

success_message.str: With a snarl, the <npc_name> screams to life!

failure_message.str: You flip the switch, but nothing happens.

description: This electric combat chainsaw is on, and is continuously draining power.  Use it to turn it off.
A short, sharp double-edged dagger made to be gripped in the palm, with the blade protruding between the fingers.
Five pieces of rebar sharpened to cruel points and strapped to a brace fastened at the wrist and forearm on both arms.  The next bub better watch out.
This is a vintage spike bayonet for the British Lee Enfield No. 4 rifle, featuring a distinct cruciform blade and socket-based mounting system.
//: VERY not intended for usage unmounted.

description: An essential tool within any 20th-century Japanese soldier's toolbox, the Type 30 is a massive, single-edged sword-style bayonet intended for use with Arisaka rifles and even light machineguns.  Possessing a J-shaped quillon guard for hooking an opponent's weapon during combat, the bayonet, when dismounted, acts like a particularly sizable machete.
A curved sword used by the Raj of India in the 16th century, a talwar is usually impeccably decorated and able to take off a limb with a single swipe.

A Turkish sabre, the kilij is quite a bit heavier than most Middle Eastern sabres and has a distinctive wide tip called a yelman, which gives it vicious cutting power but means it requires a special scabbard.
